title: 112_s1733
content: The Act titled "Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States Act of 2011" establishes a commission to review the overseas military facility structure of the United States. The Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States is established with eight members appointed by Senate and House leaders. The Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States requires members with national security or foreign policy experience. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission will choose a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members, who serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings must be held within 30 days after establishment. The Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States will hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Chairman will call for meetings, and a majority of members constitute a quorum for hearings. The Commission's duty is to conduct a thorough study of the military facility structure overseas. The Commission will assess the number of forces needed outside the US, examine military facilities overseas, and identify amounts received from foreign sources. The Commission will evaluate military facilities overseas, including assessing the feasibility of closure or realignment, considering findings from a 2011 Government Accountability Office report, and addressing any other relevant issues. The Commission will assess military facilities overseas, including potential closure or realignment based on a 2011 Government Accountability Office report, and address any other relevant issues. The report to be submitted to the President and Congress will contain detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions, as well as a proposed overseas basing strategy. The Commission will propose an overseas basing strategy for the Department of Defense to meet current and future missions, considering fiscal constraints. The report will focus on geopolitical posturing, operational requirements, mobility, quality of life, cost, and synchronization with combatant commands. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal departments, and agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission has the authority to request necessary information from federal departments and agencies to fulfill its duties. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support upon request. The Commission can utilize the United States mails and accept gifts or donations. The Commission can accept gifts or donations of services or property. Members of the Commission will be compensated for their duties, with non-government members receiving a daily rate and government members serving without additional compensation. Members can also have their travel expenses covered. Members of the Commission are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, at authorized rates. They may also receive transportation on military aircraft for official duties, as long as it does not interfere with military operations. Staffing arrangements are also specified. The Commission may appoint an executive director and staff to assist in carrying out its duties. The total staff members, including the executive director, cannot exceed 12. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint and terminate the executive director without following civil service laws. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff members without following certain federal pay regulations. Employees from specific government agencies can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement or loss of civil service status. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary services at specific rates. Members and staff must have appropriate security clearances. The Secretary of Defense handles national security information. The Commission will terminate 45 days after submitting its report.
